Paper 5 Probability & Statistics 1

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 397, 214, 412]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 413, 841, 602]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- If additional space is needed, you should use the lined page at the end of this booklet; the question number or numbers must be clearly shown.- You should use a calculator where appropriate.- You must show all necessary working clearly; no marks will be given for unsupported answers from a calculator.- Give non-exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place for angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 632, 205, 647]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 648, 697, 678]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 50.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[72, 72, 89, 87]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 71, 875, 134]]<|/det|>
In a certain country, the weather each day is classified as fine or rainy. The probability that a fine day is followed by a fine day is 0.75 and the probability that a rainy day is followed by a fine day is 0.4. The probability that it is fine on 1 April is 0.8. The tree diagram below shows the possibilities for the weather on 1 April and 2 April.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 144, 141, 161]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 144, 551, 161]]<|/det|>
Complete the tree diagram to show the probabilities.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[848, 144, 876, 161]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[175, 170, 608, 460]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 508, 141, 525]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 508, 453, 525]]<|/det|>
Find the probability that 2 April is fine.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[848, 508, 876, 525]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[72, 72, 89, 88]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 71, 875, 103]]<|/det|> The following table gives the weekly snowfall, in centimetres, for 11 weeks in 2018 at two ski resorts, Dados and Linva. <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[141, 108, 848, 152]]<|/det|>
Dados68121510364228102216
Linva2111516032364010129
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 168, 141, 185]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 168, 662, 186]]<|/det|> Represent the information in a back-to-back stem-and-leaf diagram. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[848, 170, 876, 186]]<|/det|> [4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 71, 141, 87]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 71, 740, 87]]<|/det|>
Find the median and the interquartile range for the weekly snowfall in Dados.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[848, 71, 876, 87]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 395, 176, 413]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[176, 395, 875, 440]]<|/det|>
The median, lower quartile and upper quartile of the weekly snowfall for Linva are 12, 9 and \(32 \text{cm}\) respectively. Use this information and your answers to part (b) to compare the central tendency and the spread of the weekly snowfall in Dados and Linva.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[848, 421, 875, 440]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[72, 72, 87, 87]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 71, 875, 103]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 114, 138, 131]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 114, 774, 131]]<|/det|>
